01:53:28.000 | and leaving it in there as long as possible to earn as much interest as possible in the meantime.
01:53:33.000 | There's a concept we talk about, or actually some of the formal financial literature talks about,
01:53:40.000 | and we think about it a lot in terms of how to advise clients, and it has to do with framing,
01:53:45.000 | is that the way that you frame a discussion, the way that you frame a recommendation,
01:53:53.000 | will often affect how the client feels about it, and we don't need to go into any examples,
01:54:00.000 | but just the word "framing" is important, and a lot of times the key variable that we miss is the appropriate frame for a decision,
01:54:09.000 | and so much of successful planning is understanding those psychological tricks, just like you described.
01:54:16.000 | Okay, I see the math here, and so what I'll do is I'll give myself the permission to just simply say,
01:54:23.000 | "Well, this money here is earmarked towards this goal,"
01:54:27.000 | and we call that a "bucket of money" approach in the formal retirement distribution planning,
01:54:32.000 | so this is the bucket of money that's earmarked towards the mortgage payoff goal,
01:54:36.000 | and then just by framing it in that way, it gives you the permission to adjust your thinking about it,
01:54:41.000 | so it's a very valid and important example that you give, I think.
01:54:46.000 | Yeah, I completely agree, and one other framing thing that has kind of come up throughout our conversation
01:54:53.000 | is that psychology of "I'm happy paying off debt, I feel better being debt-free,"
01:55:03.000 | if you're a listener who feels like that, you have that psychological mindset of "I'm happy being debt-free,"
01:55:11.000 | you might be able to reframe your mortgage debt in terms of "I'm happier not leaving money on the table," like I mentioned earlier.
01:55:19.000 | And a lot of people will look at how much interest they're going to pay over the next 30 years of their mortgage,
01:55:30.000 | and they look at it and they say, "Oh my goodness, I'm going to have to pay double the cost of my house,
01:55:38.000 | and I'm going to have to pay $200,000 extra in interest by keeping this mortgage,
01:55:42.000 | so by paying it off I save myself $200,000," and so that's how it's framed in their mind.
01:55:47.000 | And if instead you tweaked that and said, "If you invested that money, you could have an extra $800,000,
01:55:55.000 | so would you rather have $800,000 and have paid an extra $200,000 along the way,
01:56:01.000 | or would you rather have not paid that extra $200,000 along the way but also not have that extra $800,000 in the bank?"
01:56:07.000 | And if you can reframe it like that, you might be able to psychologically trick yourself into being okay with it
01:56:15.000 | for the purpose of understanding that it might be mathematically optimal to do so.
01:56:21.000 | My kind of summary statement to pick up on that and kind of give my summary statement,
01:56:25.000 | and I'll give you kind of an opportunity to give your summary,
01:56:30.000 | is based upon the premise that you're going to invest effectively and successfully.
01:56:40.000 | So that's the primary premise, because if your decision is, "Should I choose to pay extra on debt or should I consume the money?"
01:56:46.000 | you're always going to be better off paying the extra on debt.
01:56:49.000 | But if the comparison is, "Should I choose to pay extra on debt or should I invest in this other quality investment opportunity
01:56:58.000 | that has the potential and probability of a higher rate of return when adjusted for risk, when adjusted for other variables?"
01:57:07.000 | then the challenge will often come down to, "Do I want to follow the math or do I want to follow the emotion?"
01:57:13.000 | And the problem with conceiving of the math is that it's so long-term.
01:57:17.000 | I think that if I said to most people, you know, gave you the example, "You're paying extra on your mortgage,"
01:57:24.000 | and I said, "Well, you have the opportunity at the grocery store this month to stock up on groceries,"
01:57:30.000 | because there's a 50% sale, so there's an extra month on grocery, so you can stock up at this big sale opportunity.
01:57:41.000 | But in order to do that, you can't send extra money toward the mortgage.
01:57:46.000 | Then most people, I think, because that's such a short-term opportunity, would probably jump at that and say,
01:57:52.000 | "You know what? I'm going to take the extra money that I was going to send to the mortgage
01:57:55.000 | and I'm going to stock up on groceries, which will effectively get me through two months, which just saves me a massive amount."
01:58:01.000 | Now, that's kind of an extreme example, but it's easy to say, "Oh, yes, I see that buying this thing in bulk on this discount
01:58:07.000 | will be better than paying extra on my mortgage because it saves me a lot more."
01:58:11.000 | It's very short-term. It's very tangible.
01:58:14.000 | The flip side is all you've got to do is just figure out a way to frame the discussion and apply it in such a way
01:58:20.000 | that you can see it going forward and in the long term, because in the long term, mathematically,
01:58:28.000 | if you have a higher expected rate of return from your investment opportunity when adjusted for risk,
01:58:36.000 | when adjusted for all those other factors, you're always going to be better off investing.
01:58:41.000 | It often comes down to the math versus the emotion, and you can adjust the emotion.
01:58:46.000 | However, I would say emotion is 100% a valid planning concept, and you have to consider it in your own situation.
01:59:00.000 | There may be a way that you can tweak the emotion, but at the end of the day,
01:59:05.000 | the formula for wealth is always adjusting those three variables.
01:59:09.000 | What's the income? What are our expenses? And what's the rate of return that we're either earning on investments
01:59:15.000 | or paying on debt if we're still paying it?
01:59:18.000 | We've got to work on income and expenses, and then it's all mathematical as far as saying,
01:59:24.000 | "How can we refinance debt, move debt? How can we keep terms and interest rates on debts at the most optimal amount?
01:59:32.000 | And then how can we invest this money in the most ideal and optimal way?"
01:59:37.000 | And by affecting that, that will ultimately affect the amount of wealth that we have.
01:59:42.000 | That would be my summary statement, is you've got to consider both of them,
01:59:47.000 | but consider if you're framing the math properly so you can take advantage of the emotion
01:59:52.000 | and control the emotions that aren't serving you and enhance the emotions that are serving you.
